results.headline: Footballer as Life Coach (the Imaginary Kind)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Looking For Eric

results.summary_short: Steve Evets and Eric Cantona star in Ken Loach’s “Looking for Eric,” which has plenty of grit and working-class stoicism.

results.headline: In Pursuit of a Long-Distance Romance, Abandoned Long Ago

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Letters to Juliet

results.summary_short: Amanda Seyfried stars in “Letters to Juliet,” a film set in contemporary Verona, Italy, which explores two romances, one old and one new.

results.headline: Ms. Wright Meets Mr. Right, but Will They Be a Pair?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Wright

results.summary_short: In the sports romance “Just Wright,” Queen Latifah plays an unmarried physical therapist who is, in her own words, “the perfect homegirl.”

results.headline: A City of Warehoused Souls

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Here and There

results.summary_short: In “Here and There,” a depressed New Yorker opens up in dreary Belgrade.

results.headline: An Immigrant Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Entre Nos

results.summary_short: In “Entre Nos,” an abandoned immigrant fights for her children in Queens.

results.headline: A Father Who Needs Some Supervision

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daddy Longlegs

results.summary_short: In Benny and Josh Safdie’s new film, Lenny is a reckless, selfish and irresponsible father to two sons, but he is also entirely devoted to them.

results.headline: An Actor’s Not-So-Big Break

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Best Worst Movie

results.summary_short: “Best Worst Movie” shows how a disaster of a horror movie and its “stars” became cult favorites.

results.headline: Finding Meaning in Cleaning
results.display_title: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle

results.summary_short: “The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle” is like “Clerks” reimagined by William S. Burroughs.

results.headline: Splashing Through Comedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Swimsuit Issue

results.summary_short: “The Swimsuit Issue” follows a crew of middle-aged men, not particularly buff or aquatic, as they train for a world championship in synchronized swimming.

results.headline: Ladies Loved

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Last Five Girlfriends

results.summary_short: The British romantic comedy “My Last Five Girlfriends,” loosely based on the novel “On Love” by Alain de Botton, is all concept and very little comedy.

results.headline: Dystopia Animated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Metropia

results.summary_short: Tarik Saleh’s dystopian vision of a depleted, smog-engulfed, financially collapsed Europe in the year 2024 seems a touch too close to home.

results.headline: Environmental Action

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Climate of Change

results.summary_short: In “Climate of Change,” the director, Brian Hill, has traveled the planet to assemble portraits of citizens who are thinking globally and acting locally.

results.headline: In Japan, the Children Are Buying Bugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beetle Queen Conquers Tokyo

results.summary_short: “Beetle Queen Conquers Tokyo” says less about Japan than it does about America’s continuing fascination with modern Japanese culture.

results.headline: A Road Trip to the End of the Road

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Barking Water

results.summary_short: Two former lovers reunite for a final road trip in Indian Country as one nears death in Sterlin Harjo’s spare, cosmically solemn film “Barking Water.”

results.headline: How to Say ‘Greed Is Good’ in Hindi

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Badmaash Company

results.summary_short: Parmeet Sethi’s “Badmaash Company” considers corruption and redemption in modern India.

results.headline: Channel Crossing of the Urgent Kind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome

results.summary_short: Philippe Loiret’s film depicts the relationship between an illegal immigrant in France and the coach who helps him try to reach Britain.

results.headline: A Healing House

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gravity Was Everywhere Back Then

results.summary_short: “Gravity Was Everywhere Back Then” is the story of a man who built a house as a healing machine for his wife, hoping to save her from cancer.

results.headline: Awwwwww, Ewwww, Who’s a Good Baby?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Babies

results.summary_short: “Babies,” a documentary by Thomas Balmès, chronicles the first year in the lives of four far-flung infants.

results.headline: Wrestling With One’s Conscience

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ocean of Pearls

results.summary_short: In “Ocean of Pearls,” a young Sikh man whose parents emigrated from India to Toronto wrestles with his conscience but never strays far from Sikh virtue.

results.headline: Geriatric Delinquents, Rampaging Through Suburbia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trash Humpers

results.summary_short: Harmony Korine’s “Trash Humpers” follows the gleeful, gross exploits of a quartet of old degenerates.
